body.head: Help (User Manual)
body.p: This document provides a general introduction to using . It describes the basic functions of the software. Please note that not all of the options described here are necessarily available in every edition using . This is due to the fact that contents have to be prepared accordingly and projects using have their own edition guidelines and concepts. Furthermore, some versions may contain more options than mentioned in this document due to edition-specific enhancements.

div.head: User interface
div.p: The user interface of is divided into several sections. At the top and bottom borders of the window you find and that provide access to all major Edirom functions. The space in between is called . At the top right corner of the is the so-called .

The is the space between and . In this space all internal application windows are opened and arranged in order to show contents of an edition or to give access to further application functions. The internal application windows cannot be dragged out of this area. See for further details.
The at the bottom of the gives access to content-related functions on the left, and meta-functions on the right.

div.p: The can be opened by clicking the (magnifying lens) on the . It will perform a text-based search on all edition contents.

figure.head: Screenshot of the Search window after performing a search operation.

div.p: After performing a search operation, all resulting hits are grouped as one result entry for every corresponding content object (text document, annotation, etc.). Furthermore, individual hits are highlighted within their surrounding context.
Clicking on an entry's title or on a highlighted search hit opens the corresponding content object with all search hits highlighted.
If a search operation scores more than three hits per entry a link named show all hits will appear.
The offers quick access to the objects contained in the edition, which are opened by mouse click in a new on the current .

figure.head: Screenshot of the navigator. Note the scrollbar on the right.

div.p: The number of objects held by the may exceed the actual size of the panel. In this case a scrollbar at the right side of the window permits to scroll through the contents of the . The mouse wheel may be used as well.
Although the is fixed to the top right corner of the workspace, it is possible to resize and even to reduce it to a narrow bar below the button by drag-and-drop on its left or bottom edge.

The controls synchronous navigation to corresponding places in all open source or edition windows. It is based on the structural information (e.g., numbers, scenes, bars, text lines) inherent to the source and edition objects.

The consists of one or two drop-down menus, depending on wether the selected number/scene in the upper drop-down menu provides multiple options for navigating through the edition and/or sources. Navigation by bar as the default option allows displaying and navigating through all corresponding occurrences of a particular bar synchronously. Furthermore, if provided, the second drop-down menu allows to select Navigation by text line, which allows displaying and navigating by referring to corresponding text lines.

A particular bar or text line may be selected by using the slide control. By clicking the Display button, all corresponding edition or source windows get synchonized. Browsing backward or forward simultaneously within the open sources and editions is achieved using the two arrows to the left and right of the Display button.

figure.head: Concordance navigator with sample configuration for navigation by bar.

div.p: Any content object contained in the edition opens in a separate window, called Content window. The Content windows can be manipulated within the program in virtually the same way as normal operating system windows.
Windows can be arranged on the by dragging the title bars; they may be resized by dragging any edge or corner of the window frame.

Each open window is represented by a button in the showing the window title, a feature that might be known from certain computer operating systems. Clicking on the button allows toggling between minimizing and extending window function.
When multiple windows are open, the entry in the indicates which window is currently active.

div.head: Title bar
div.p: Along the top edge of the window is a title bar that contains the name of the displayed object.
At the right end of the title bar there are three buttons:

div.p: Below the title bar each Content window has a . At the very left of the Window toolbar there is a for switching between . Further content specific features may be accessible through the , such as , , , and .

At the bottom edge Content windows may contain a view specific with tools for manipulating the object displayed in the window. The availability is dynamic and depends on the object currently on display. Specifically, in windows showing images (facsimiles) of musical sources or editions the includes buttons for toggling between the two display modes, i.e. the and the .

div.head: Views
div.p: Views offer different perspectives on the content of the currently open window, e.g., , , and . In certain cases, other views (such as Synopsis, Preliminary Remarks, or Source Description) may be included.

The entry is available on a window's menu if the content object of the window is a text-based object, e.g., a TEI file representing the Preface, the Editorial Guidelines, the Text Edition, the List of Sources, or the Source Evaluation. The appears in a form similar to that of a website and may include links to other content (depending on the edition, the appearance of the actual link may vary).
The view shows images of a source or an edition and provides controls for navigating in it.
The of Content windows displayed in view may contain the following additional control menus:

list.item: allows configuration of basic options such as the display of text versions.
allows configuration of superimposed Annotation symbols. The drop-down menu provides access to the following functions:

Show/hide annotations
This option permits to display Critical Report shaped as buttons superimposed on facsimiles, images, or text. The user can filter by category (see below). In each source or edition window, only relating to that particular source or edition are shown. If you mouse over an annotation symbol, a tooltip shows preview information concerning the annotation. Click on the symbol to open the annotation in its separate window (for a detailed description see ).

Categories…
This sub-menu shows all categories (if any) of contained in the current source or edition and allows activating/deactivating their display in the view.
This option allows to control the superimposing of bar numbers for the source or edition on display. Bar numbers appear in the center of the corresponding bar.
allows skipping to specific sections such as numbers and scenes. In contrast to the , the Go to… function affects only the currently active Content window.

div.p: The of Content windows displayed in contains the following controls for navigating the source or edition images:

In this mode, the provides combo boxes and input fields required for navigating to any place in the respective source or edition (e.g., number or scene, bar, bar range; for details see below).

The slider allows zooming in and out of the image currently displayed.
The zoom level can also be increased or decreased using the scroll function of the mouse wheel.

Insert a page or bar number, or click on the respective arrows for navigating to the desired place in the source or edition. When entering a number in the number field, a filtered list of possible numbers will appear. The numbering corresponds to the one applied by the editor to the specific source or edition; it does not necessarily begin by 1. Furthermore, it might include any alphanumeric character.

div.p: Selecting from the menu shows the XML data (e.g. the MEI or TEI encoding) of the current content object. In this view, the following controls are present in the :

div.p:
In , Annotations within an edition's Critical Report can be accessed in different ways.
(1) Icons representing Annotations in the editions and sources provide essential information via tooltip (mouseover).
(2) A click on the icon opens the full view of the Critical Report entry.
(3) A list view of Annotations contained in the Critical Report is also accessible through the .
Moreover, provides additional means for accessing individual Annotations by labelling them according to specific .

figure.head: Screenshot of the edition with annotation icons and tooltip of a single annotation.

div.p: The Annotations window shows readings or individual Annotations from the Critical Report of the current edition. The default appearance is a list of all Annotations with three columns:

list.item: Indicates the order of the annotations.
Gives the heading or lemma of the annotation; often used to give a first impression of the annotation's subject matter, or to indicate the position of an annotation.
Indicates the assigned to a given annotation.

div.p: Clicking on a column header will re-sort the list on the basis of this column’s data, a second click on the same column header will reverse the sort order. When moving the mouse over the column header an arrowhead will appear to the right of the column title, giving access to a context menu that enables:

figure.p: setting sort order, and
showing/hiding columns.

div.p: It is also possible to apply a filter on the respective column. For more details, see .

figure.head: List of Annotations showing options provided in a column's context menu.

div.p: Double-clicking on an Annotation entry in the list switches to a full view of all the individual Annotation. It presents, along with the text and further identifying parameters, snippet views of all related sources and editions in an overview grid; double-clicking on a single image opens the corresponding source in its .
The of the Individual annotation window shows the following controls:

figure.p: Returns to the complete list of annotations.
Moves to the previous annotation with respect to filters and sort options applied in the list of annotations (see ).
Moves to the next annotation with respect to filters and sort options applied in in the list of annotations (see ).
Opens detail views of all sources corresponding to the current annotation.
Only available when has been operated before, closes all respective windows.

div.p: Annotations are typically assigned to one or more , each of which may be associated with a specific symbol. The symbol is likewise displayed on the Annotation button in the . It is thus possible to determine the type of Annotation content by its symbol.

div.p: Filtering annotations by text contained in the title (heading, lemma, position) as well as by is possible from the list options (context menu) in the of the Annotations windows. This filtering concerns only the Annotations object (in both and Individual annotation view).

In any , the display of Annotation buttons can be filtered by . This function is available only from the menu ‘Annotations’ in . All Annotations that belong to at least one of the selected are shown in the facsimile or edition. Please note that Filtering by multiple will display all Annotations assigned to at least one of these .

div.head: Help (Edirom User Manual)
div.p: The Help (Edirom User Manual) window is (in contrast to content related windows) a stand-alone window and can only be opened once. Clicking the Help button will toggle show/hide for the help window, or will bring it to the foreground if hidden behind other windows.
